Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Study of the Transnational Surrogacy Industry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Medical tourism, including for reproductive services like surrogacy, is a growing market that is largely unregulated. Surrogacy, in particular, is highly controversial and only legal in a handful of jurisdictions globally. An increasing number of people are traveling across borders to hire women to gestate and birth children. However, very little is known about this process including how certain locations become hubs for international surrogacy, the experiences of women serving as surrogate mothers, and the impact of this industry on local politics and economics in newly-established surrogacy hubs. This project will deliver much needed empirical data on the operation and organization of the industry, as well as the experiences of surrogate mothers and intended parents. The study will also contribute to debates about the feasibility and merits of regulating surrogacy at the international level. This study will provide a platform for presenting the voices of the women who are most affected by this industry but are often unheard in legal and moral debates about surrogacy. This project will be of interest to policy makers, health care providers, and users.


This study will contribute to an ongoing discussion of the relationship between developments in medical technologies and the emergence of new global markets. This research addresses the intellectual, material, and social problem of regulating new technological possibilities in a globalized world. This project is a multi-sited ethnographic study of the surrogacy industry. Employing a combination of observation, interviews, and archival research, the investigators will collect information about 1) the history and organization of the surrogacy industry, 2) the key actors, including the history of their involvement in surrogacy, and 3) the everyday processes through which commercial surrogacy is negotiated and experienced. The researchers will investigate how and why nations and communities became a global surrogacy destination, how the surrogacy industry is organized, and how the market reacts to changing regulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant was used to support the completion of an ethnographic study the transnational surrogacy industry in Mexico. The DDRI supported extended hands-on training for the Co-PI in qualitative research methods including participant observation, interviews, and content analysis. Over the course of the three years, the researcher conducted multi-sited ethnographic research in Tabasco, Quintana-Roo, and Mexico City, Mexico with supplementary research in Spain and the United States. Rather than conducting the ethnography at one site, the Co-PI observed a variety of participants in the surrogacy industry as they conducted their daily business. Through observation, interviews, document analysis, and archival research, the researcher collected information about the history and organization of the Mexican surrogacy industry, the key actors, and the everyday processes through which commercial surrogacy is negotiated and experienced.  In addition to observation, the researcher conducted in-depth, semi-structured interviews with 120 actors in the surrogacy industry, including 45 surrogates, 26 intended parents, 15 surrogacy agency staff members, 15 government officials, and eight doctors.

Drawing on this wide-range of data, this dissertation analyzes the technical, legal, and social processes that led to the emergence of Mexico as a new site in the global market for baby making and the effect of this industry on the actors involved. This study contributes to an ongoing discussion of the relationship between developments in medical technologies and the emergence of new global markets. This research addresses the intellectual, material, and social problem of regulating new technological possibilities in a globalized world. The findings from this study provide insight into the practices of the transnational surrogacy industry, for which there is little data and transparency. The project describes the history and operations of the Mexican surrogacy industry and the difficulties that arise at each stage of the process from recruiting intended parents and surrogates, to scheduling embryo transfers, negotiating payments, and obtaining birth certificates. The Co-PI found that actors often have divergent views and attach different meanings and values to various aspects of the surrogacy process, which leads to misunderstandings and conflict. This project offers a critique of normative claims about the surrogacy industry based on abstract, ostensibly universal values by analyzing the values that emerge in relation to new technological possibilities in specific historical, religious, and social contexts. These findings can inform the creation of new international standards and regulations for surrogacy.

Findings from the study were published in an article entitled Producing Moral Palatability in the Mexican Surrogacy Marker in the leading journal of sociology and gender, Gender & Society.  The article describes one of the key findings of the research: surrogacy agencies draw on a perceived dichotomy between altruism and commodification to facilitate the surrogacy market by rendering it morally palatable to consumers and by disciplining surrogates to create a docile and compliant labor force. Debates about surrogacy, both academic and legislative, often focus on whether women should be paid to act as surrogates. Many countries and jurisdictions, including New York and Canada, are currently debating whether or not to legalize paid surrogacy. These debates are often premised on the idea that commercial surrogacy is inherently more exploitative than altruistic surrogacy. However, this research demonstrates that the very dichotomy between altruism and commercialism can be exploited to produce compliant surrogates and sustain the surrogacy industry. The researcher found that a rhetoric of altruism as a feminine virtue enables surrogacy agencies to cultivate a docile workforce that cannot advocate for their own financial gain. This article received awards from the American Sociological Association, the Society for Women Sociologists, and the Gender Studies Program at the University of Southern California. The article has also been disseminated amongst non-governmental organizations and referenced in drafting policy recommendations for local and international regulators.

Findings from the study have been disseminated through public talks at academic conferences, thematic workshops and symposia. Findings were also disseminated at several international conferences regarding surrogacy regulation. One such conference included delegates from major international organizations such as the World Health Organization and the United Nations. Several non-governmental organizations have incorporated the findings of this research into their public statements and policy recommendations for surrogacy. A second article based on this research is under review at a leading journal for medical Sociology. The Co-PI is currently in the process of writing a book proposal based on the dissertation research.
